lessons.title: Introduction to HTML
lessons.content:
HTML stands for Hyper Text Markup Language. It is the standard markup language for creating web pages. HTML describes the structure of a webpage using elements. These elements tell the browser how to display the content. Example: A heading and a paragraph:

This is a heading

This is a paragraph.

subTopics.title: What is HTML?
subTopics.content: HTML (HyperText Markup Language) is the standard language for creating web pages. It structures content using elements like headings, paragraphs, images, and links. HTML works with CSS for styling and JavaScript for interactivity..

subTopics.title: Why use HTML?
subTopics.content:
Defines Structure ➡️ Organizes content with headings, paragraphs, lists, etc.

Works with CSS & JavaScript ➡️ CSS styles the page, and JavaScript adds interactivity.

SEO-Friendly ➡️ Helps search engines understand content. 

Universal & Easy ➡️ Supported by all browsers and easy to learn. 

Multimedia Support ➡️ Allows images, videos, and audio integration.

subTopics.title: Basic HTML Syntax
subTopics.content: HTML uses tags like <html>, <body>, <h1>.

code: <title>This is the Title of the Page</title>

lessons.title: TEXT
lessons.content:
When creating a web page, you add tags (known as markup) to the contents of the page. These tags provide extra meaning and allow browsers to show users the appropriate structure for the page, 

In this chapter we focus on how to add markup to the text that appears on your pages. You will learn about: 

● Structural markup: the elements that you can use to describe both headings and paragraphs 

● Semantic markup: which provides extra information; such as where emphasis is placed in a sentence, that something you have written is a quotation (and who said it), the meaning of acronyms, and so on

subTopics.title: Headings
subTopics.content:
<h1> <h2> <h3> <h4> <h5> <h6>
HTML has six 'levels' of headings

<h1> is used for main headings <h2> is used for subheadings

If there are further sections under the subheadings then the <h3> element is used, and so on... 

Browsers display the contents of headings at different sizes. The contents of an <h1> element is the largest, and the contents of an <h6> element is the smallest. The exact size at which each browser shows the headings can vary slightly. Users can also adjust the size of text in their browser. You will see how to control the size of text, its color, and the fonts used when we come to look at CSS.

subTopics.title: Paragraphs
subTopics.content:
To create a paragraph, surround the words that make up the paragraph with an opening

tag and closing

tag. By default, a browser will show each paragraph on a new line with some space between it and any subsequent paragraphs.

subTopics.title: Bold & Italic
subTopics.content: By enclosing words in the tags **Bold Text** we can make characters appear bold. The element also represents a section of text that would be presented in a visually different way (for example key words in a paragraph) By enclosing words in the tags and we can make characters appear italic. The element also represents a section of text that would be said in a different way from surrounding content (such as technical terms, names of ships, foreign words, thoughts, or other terms that would usually be italicized).

subTopics.title: Superscripts and subscripts
subTopics.content: Superscripts and subscripts are characters that are slightly above or below the normal line of type. They are often smaller than the rest of the text.

subTopics.title: <sup>
subTopics.content: The <sup> element is used to contain characters that should be superscript such as the suffixes of dates or mathematical concepts like raising a number to a power such as 22.

subTopics.title: <sub>
subTopics.content: The <sub> element is used to contain characters that should be subscript. It is commonly used with foot notes or chemical formulas such as H2O.

code: The amount of CO2 in the atmosphere grew by 2ppm in 20091.

subTopics.title: White Space
subTopics.content: In order to make code easier to read, web page authors often add extra spaces or start some elements on new lines. When the browser comes across two or more spaces next to each other, it only displays one space. Similarly, when it comes across a line break, it treats it as a single space. This is known as white space collapsing.

code: The moon is drifting away from Earth.
The moon is drifting away from Earth.

subTopics.title: Strong & Emphasis
subTopics.content: The <strong> element indicates that its content has strong importance, while the <em> element indicates emphasis. By default, browsers will show the contents of a <strong> element in bold, and the contents of an <em> element in italic.

subTopics.title: Quotations
subTopics.content: There are two elements commonly used for marking up quotations: <blockquote> and <q>. A <blockquote> element is used for longer quotes that take up an entire paragraph, while a <q> element is used for shorter quotes that sit within a paragraph.

subTopics.title: Abbreviations & Acronyms
subTopics.content: When you use an abbreviation or an acronym, the <abbr> element can be used. A title attribute on the opening tag is used to specify the full term.

subTopics.title: Citations & Definitions
subTopics.content: The <cite> element can be used to indicate where the citation is from. It can be used for a person's name or a book, song, or movie title.

lessons.title: HTML Attributes
lessons.content: HTML attributes provide additional information about HTML elements.

subTopics.title: Common Attributes
subTopics.content: Common attributes include id, class, style, and title.

subTopics.title: Attribute Syntax
subTopics.content: Attributes are added to the opening tag of an element and are written as name-value pairs.

subTopics.title: Global Attributes
subTopics.content: Global attributes can be used on any HTML element, such as lang, dir, and hidden.

lessons.title: HTML Headings
lessons.content: HTML headings are defined with the <h1> to <h6> tags.

subTopics.title: Heading Levels
subTopics.content: There are six levels of headings, from <h1> to <h6>, with <h1> being the highest level.

code: <title>This is the Title of the Page</title>

subTopics.title: Using Headings
subTopics.content: Headings are used to create a hierarchical structure for your content.

subTopics.title: Semantic Importance
subTopics.content: Headings provide semantic meaning to the content, helping search engines and screen readers understand the structure of the page.

lessons.title: HTML Lists
lessons.content: HTML lists allow web developers to group a set of related items in lists.

subTopics.title: Unordered Lists
subTopics.content: Unordered lists are created with the <ul> tag and list items are added with the <li> tag.

code: <title>This is the Title of the Page</title>

subTopics.title: Ordered Lists
subTopics.content: Ordered lists are created with the <ol> tag and list items are added with the <li> tag.

subTopics.title: Description Lists
subTopics.content: Description lists are created with the <dl> tag and terms are defined with the <dt> and <dd> tags.

lessons.title: Introduction to CSS
lessons.content:
CSS stands for Cascading Style Sheets.

CSS describes how HTML elements are to be displayed on screen, paper, or in other media.

CSS saves a lot of work. It can control the layout of multiple web pages all at once.

External stylesheets are stored in CSS files.

subTopics.title: What is CSS?
subTopics.content: CSS (Cascading Style Sheets) is a style sheet language used for describing the presentation of a document written in HTML. CSS describes how elements should be rendered on screen, on paper, in speech, or on other media.

subTopics.title: Why use CSS?
subTopics.content:
Separation of Content & Presentation ➡️ Keeps content separate from design.

Consistent Design ➡️ Applies the same styles across multiple pages.

Responsive Design ➡️ Adjusts layout for different screen sizes.

Easy Maintenance ➡️ Updates styles in one place for all pages.

Accessibility ➡️ Helps screen readers and search engines understand content.

subTopics.title: CSS Syntax
subTopics.content: CSS uses selectors to target HTML elements and declarations to style them. Selectors are followed by curly braces containing property-value pairs.

lessons.title: Introduction to JavaScript
lessons.content:
JavaScript is the programming language of the Web.

JavaScript is used to program the behavior of web pages.

JavaScript can change HTML content.

JavaScript can change HTML attributes.

JavaScript can change HTML styles.

JavaScript can hide HTML elements.

JavaScript can show HTML elements.

subTopics.title: What is JavaScript?
subTopics.content: JavaScript is a programming language that enables you to create dynamically updating content, control multimedia, animate images, and much more. It is used to enhance web pages and make them interactive.

subTopics.title: Why use JavaScript?
subTopics.content:
Dynamic Content ➡️ Updates content without reloading the page.

Interactive Elements ➡️ Adds animations, sliders, and other interactive features.

Form Validation ➡️ Checks user input before submitting data.

Browser Compatibility ➡️ Works on all modern browsers.

Server Communication ➡️ Sends and receives data from servers.

subTopics.title: JavaScript Syntax
subTopics.content: JavaScript uses variables, operators, functions, and objects to create interactive web pages. Statements are terminated with semicolons.
